conclusion: Principles of shadow formation depend on the relative position of the light source to the object.
Current shadows suggest the light source is positioned towards the front left of the objects.
When the light source moves to the back right, it changes the angle at which light hits the objects, affecting both the position and size of the shadows.
Shadows will move towards the front left because the light source is now behind and to the right of the objects.
Object A's shadow will move towards the front left and elongate due to the object's height.
Object B's shadow will move towards the front left and become longer and more stretched.
Object C's shadow will shift towards the front left and likely elongate due to its cylindrical shape.
Object D's shadow will move towards the front left, elongate, and may appear more distorted due to its circular shape.
Shadows will generally become longer because the light source is further away and at a lower angle relative to the objects.
Object A's shadow will become longer and thinner.
Object B's shadow will become longer and more stretched.
Object C's shadow will elongate and may appear more oval-shaped.
Object D's shadow will elongate and may appear more distorted.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift towards the front left and generally become longer due to the change in angle and distance of the light source.
